section.p: The aim of this project is to provid an integration platform for Subversion into the existing environment Visual Studio .NET. By making a plugin in Visual Studio .NET the revision control system could be available for a huge amount of new programmers. The intention is to make the .NET wrapper layer platform independent so that it easily could be used in other applications.
The group will have weekly meetings with the HIO/IU supervisor, Eva H.Vihovde Fridays at 2am.

Every Monday from 8:30 and Fridays from 13:30 am the group will work at the dedicated school PC. The group will work together until all the group members are familiar with the software to be used. At a later stage in the project it would be possible to work separately at individual home computers as the communication easily could happen via instant messaging systems.
To enforce an overall consistent look of the code common guidelines for source code is composed.
Subversion will be used for revision control.

To verify the sanity of the system at any given moment, and to catch regression bugs (things that used to work, but breaks due to later changes) we will conduct continuous unit tests using the NUnit testing framework.

We hope to make the .NET wrapper layer available as a standalone unit for use in other applications. We will provide NAnt build scripts that will enable it to be built without requiring the user to have Visual Studio.NET installed.
Code reviews will be performed. (Guidelines for code review to be discussed)

Guidelines for how the documentation to be written in xml will be composed. The intention is to transform theses XML documents into both HTML and into a format suitable for printing(XSL Formatting Objects) using XSL.

The coding required to make the plugin is classified as advanced programming. There are some open source code for addins of common revision control systems and available code of addins in .NET in general.
